articles.author: BBC News
articles.description: The Sunday papers are splashed with stories on digital IDs and the resident doctors' strikes.
articles.title: Newspaper headlines: 'Britain's real immigration crisis' and 'Carry on, doctor!'

articles.author: BBC News
articles.description: The BBC has reportedly launched an investigation into alleged cocaine use by two Strictly Come Dancing stars.
articles.title: BBC reportedly launches probe into Strictly 'drug use'

articles.author: BBC News
articles.description: The mystery of a dead platypus, a Nazi submarine and a 45-day voyage has long remained unsolved - until now.
articles.title: How the mystery of Winston Churchill's dead platypus was finally solved

articles.author: BBC News
articles.description: Switzerland spends almost $500m a year on protective structures. Is it worth it - or, as some suggest, should people move away from the mountain villages at risk?
articles.title: Why glaciers are threatening to wipe out more mountain villages

articles.author: BBC News
articles.description: Ukraine says Russian missiles hit Mykolaiv, while Russia blames a huge oil blaze in Sochi on Ukrainian drones.
articles.title: Ukraine and Russia strikes hit homes and oil depot near Black Sea

articles.author: BBC News
articles.description: The ex-Labour leader wants supporters to come up with a name for his new party.
articles.title: Jeremy Corbyn's new party needs a name and it's trickier than you might think

articles.author: BBC News
articles.description: We speak to the women infected with the Zika virus in Brazil a decade ago about what life is like with their children now.
articles.title: Ten years after the Zika outbreak: What happened to the babies born with microcephaly?

articles.author: BBC News
articles.description: The TV Burp host says his stepfather's young death made him re-evaluate his original career in medicine.
articles.title: Harry Hill says his stepfather's death made him switch careers from medicine to comedy

articles.author: BBC News
articles.description: The offence of promoting illegal crossings online would carry a sentence of up to five years in prison.
articles.title: New offence to target online posts for small-boat Channel crossings

articles.author: BBC News
articles.description: Tan lines are seemingly back in fashion, but experts warn the trend's rise could fuel dangerous sunburn habits.
articles.title: Tan lines are back in fashion. But can you get the look safely?
